page.title: 02KENDAL LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: In Roman times, Westmorland belonged to the{Kingdom of Strathclyde,}but in the{Middle Ages}the Parish Church was under the{diocese of York.}Abbot Hall was so called because the Abbot collected his{tithes}there. There are 4 bridges across the Kent. Miller bridge was originally made of wood. The latest bridge was built in 1887. Wool was the source of Kendal's wealth in the past.{Pannus mihi panis}is the town's motto.{Kendal Green}dye was produced by{Flemish dyers}in the C14. {Tenter Fields}and the{Fleece Inn}are reminders of the wool trade. Kendal had an open market and its own {Moote Hall.}It was granted a charter in 1575.{Bull-baiting}took place on {Beast Banks}and the Yards could be protected against the Scots.{Bonnie {Prince Charlie}came in 1745.
